p: The common feature among quinones is the presence of two carbonyl groups in a six-membered unsaturated ring (carbonyl groups can also be on adjacent rings). They are classified into three main groups: benzoquinones which have two carbonyl groups in a benzene ring (Q1), naphthoquinones, which have two carbonyl groups on one of the rings in naphthalene (Q2) and anthraquinones, which are derivatives of anthracene (Q3) ( Figure 7). They are found in the leaves, seeds, and woody parts of higher plants, in some fungi and bacteria but rarely in higher animals. Quinones have been reported to have antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antibiotic, antimicrobial, and anticancer activities (El-Najjar et al., 2011).
